content.$t: endyear: 1500, displaydate: 500 BC, headline: A brief history of the banana business, text: The first accounts of banana cultivation are written in India.  Soon, humans disperse the fruit throughout the Middle East, Africa and Europe.  A millenium later, Spanish missionary Father Tomás de Barlanga brings bananas to the Caribbean. , media: http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-iJI7R_Drkzk/Uw1xOXpRwCI/AAAAAAAAAYQ/MVeJTN7EA-k/s1600/banana.jpg, mediacredit: blogspot.com, type: title, background: #333333

gsx$headline.$t: A brief history of the banana business

gsx$text.$t: The first accounts of banana cultivation are written in India.  Soon, humans disperse the fruit throughout the Middle East, Africa and Europe.  A millenium later, Spanish missionary Father Tomás de Barlanga brings bananas to the Caribbean.

content.$t: endyear: 1870, displaydate: 1870, headline: Bananas arrive in North America, text: American captain Lorenzo Dow Baker buys 160 bunches of Gros Michel bananas in Jamaica, loads them into his schooner’s empty hold and speeds back to the U.S. to sell the fruit for $2 a bunch. , media: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/ba/Lorenzo_Dow_Baker_LC.jpg, mediacredit: upload.wikimedia.org, background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: American captain Lorenzo Dow Baker buys 160 bunches of Gros Michel bananas in Jamaica, loads them into his schooner’s empty hold and speeds back to the U.S. to sell the fruit for $2 a bunch.

content.$t: endyear: 1885, displaydate: 1885, headline: Boston Fruit booms, text: Due to rising demand for bananas, Baker founds the first banana importing company, Boston Fruit (which will become United Fruit, and eventually Chiquita).  Five years later, rival company Standard Fruit emerges in New Orleans, the main port for U.S. banana imports.  Standard Fruit later changes its name to Dole. , media: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/14/1894_banana_transport2_Jamaica.png, mediacredit: upload.wikimedia.org, background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: Due to rising demand for bananas, Baker founds the first banana importing company, Boston Fruit (which will become United Fruit, and eventually Chiquita).  Five years later, rival company Standard Fruit emerges in New Orleans, the main port for U.S. banana imports.  Standard Fruit later changes its name to Dole.

content.$t: endyear: 1903, displaydate: 1903, headline: "Panama disease" strikes, text: A deadly strain of the banana root disease Tropical race 4 (TR4), or “Panama Disease,” afflicts thousands of acres of banana producing land throughout Central and South America.  Over the next half of the century, United Fruit will employ heavy pesticide use and expand into thousands of acres of virgin rain forest to develop new plantations. The rampant practice of mono-cropping, or growing only one species in a large area, makes banana plants especially vulnerable to the disease.    , media: http://www.abc.net.au/news/image/4729800-3x2-940x627.jpg, mediacredit: www.abc.net.au, background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: A deadly strain of the banana root disease Tropical race 4 (TR4), or “Panama Disease,” afflicts thousands of acres of banana producing land throughout Central and South America.  Over the next half of the century, United Fruit will employ heavy pesticide use and expand into thousands of acres of virgin rain forest to develop new plantations. The rampant practice of mono-cropping, or growing only one species in a large area, makes banana plants especially vulnerable to the disease.

content.$t: endyear: 1904, displaydate: 1904, headline: Network expansion, text: United Fruit implements a radio technology that allows instant communication between approaching cargo vessels and plantations.  The tropical radio system allows more precise harvesting of bananas to ensure rapid delivery of the fruit, which has a shelf life of ten days or less. Around this time, United Fruit also receives a ninety-nine-year, unlimited license to build railroads in Guatemala and cultivate all lands alongside the newly laid tracks. Not long after, the company will own 42 percent of all land in Guatemala, pay no taxes or import duties, and control the country’s two largest enterprises, International Railways of Central America and Empress Electrica. , media: http://www.geocities.ws/ferrobanana/images/train.jpg, mediacredit: geocities.ws, background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: United Fruit implements a radio technology that allows instant communication between approaching cargo vessels and plantations.  The tropical radio system allows more precise harvesting of bananas to ensure rapid delivery of the fruit, which has a shelf life of ten days or less. Around this time, United Fruit also receives a ninety-nine-year, unlimited license to build railroads in Guatemala and cultivate all lands alongside the newly laid tracks. Not long after, the company will own 42 percent of all land in Guatemala, pay no taxes or import duties, and control the country’s two largest enterprises, International Railways of Central America and Empress Electrica.

content.$t: endyear: 1912, displaydate: 1912, headline: Invasion of Honduras, text: The U.S.-backed Honduran government challenges banana entrepreneur and future president of United Fruit Samuel Zemurray. Zemurray responds by organizing a private coup led by gangsters Guy “Machine Gun” Molony and Lee Christmas. It takes just four weeks for the country’s regime to fall. A friendlier president is installed and his first significant act is to grant Zemurray broad access to land and railroads., media: http://www.slate.com/content/dam/slate/articles/news_and_politics/history/2012/05/120518_HIST_SamZemurrayEX.jpg.CROP.rectangle3-large.jpg, mediacredit: www.slate.com, background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: The U.S.-backed Honduran government challenges banana entrepreneur and future president of United Fruit Samuel Zemurray. Zemurray responds by organizing a private coup led by gangsters Guy “Machine Gun” Molony and Lee Christmas. It takes just four weeks for the country’s regime to fall. A friendlier president is installed and his first significant act is to grant Zemurray broad access to land and railroads.

content.$t: endyear: 1930, displaydate: 1920-1930, headline: Super-size supply chain, text: United Fruit Company forms The Fruit Dispatch Company to distribute bananas in the United States. Over the years, the company implements numerous technological innovations that transform America’s consumer culture, from product-tracking systems and refrigerated shipping to huge ethylene gas chambers that control ripening and central warehouses for supermarkets. Bananas now arrive on store shelves on their final green day, and last exactly seven days before turning brown. Fruit Dispatch’s high level of standardization achieved what before seemed impossible--to provide a highly perishable, tropical fruit to U.S. consumers 365 days of the year., media: http://kamplacon.com/images/web_images/Chiquita_project_large.jpg, mediacredit: kamplacon.com, background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: United Fruit Company forms The Fruit Dispatch Company to distribute bananas in the United States. Over the years, the company implements numerous technological innovations that transform America’s consumer culture, from product-tracking systems and refrigerated shipping to huge ethylene gas chambers that control ripening and central warehouses for supermarkets. Bananas now arrive on store shelves on their final green day, and last exactly seven days before turning brown. Fruit Dispatch’s high level of standardization achieved what before seemed impossible--to provide a highly perishable, tropical fruit to U.S. consumers 365 days of the year.

content.$t: endyear: 1928, displaydate: 1928, headline: Massacre in Colombia, text: A banana workers strike in the Santa Martha banana zone of Colombia is the country’s largest labor movement yet. Strikers are labeled radicals and communists, and vigilante squads sponsored by United Fruit and trained by the U.S. military act violently against them in an encounter that results in the death of more than 1,000 bystanders and workers., media: https://spydersden.files.wordpress.com/2014/07/iu.jpg, mediacredit: spyersden.files.wordpress.com, background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: A banana workers strike in the Santa Martha banana zone of Colombia is the country’s largest labor movement yet. Strikers are labeled radicals and communists, and vigilante squads sponsored by United Fruit and trained by the U.S. military act violently against them in an encounter that results in the death of more than 1,000 bystanders and workers.

content.$t: endyear: 1935, displaydate: 1935, headline: Sigatoka strikes, text: The banana-killing pathogen “Sigatoka” disease is identified in Central America. United Fruit attempts to control the airborne illness with Bordeaux mixture, a thick, toxic chemical cocktail that causes illness and death in thousands of banana workers. Sigatoka prompts the industrialization of aerial pesticide spraying. It is still the major blight facing today’s global banana crops., media: https://bananaroots.files.wordpress.com/2014/07/jt09_0072.jpg, mediacredit: bananaroots.files.wordpress.com, background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: The banana-killing pathogen “Sigatoka” disease is identified in Central America. United Fruit attempts to control the airborne illness with Bordeaux mixture, a thick, toxic chemical cocktail that causes illness and death in thousands of banana workers. Sigatoka prompts the industrialization of aerial pesticide spraying. It is still the major blight facing today’s global banana crops.

content.$t: endyear: 1935, displaydate: 1935, headline: Banana republics reign, text: The term banana republic becomes popular after it’s used in an article in Esquire magazine. Another name, little known in the U.S. but commonplace in Latin America, is el pulpo, the Spanish word for the “octopus” used to describe United Fruit’s grasping, acquisitive nature. Though banana companies make some efforts to improve labor conditions around this time, they continue to exert nearly total political control over Central American nations., media: http://www.timetableimages.com/maritime/images/ufcdpi5.jpg, mediacredit: timetableimages.com, background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: The term banana republic becomes popular after it’s used in an article in Esquire magazine. Another name, little known in the U.S. but commonplace in Latin America, is el pulpo, the Spanish word for the “octopus” used to describe United Fruit’s grasping, acquisitive nature. Though banana companies make some efforts to improve labor conditions around this time, they continue to exert nearly total political control over Central American nations.

content.$t: endyear: 1960, displaydate: 1950-1969, headline: Ecuador, the outlier, text: In the late 1950s in Ecuador, Tenguel, a large United Fruit Company-owned plantation, falls victim to Panama disease and hundreds of workers are dismissed. A growing peasant agrarian reform movement culminates in March of 1962 when workers invade and seize Tenguel. United Fruit is forced to abandon the zone and the government undertakes contentious agrarian reform. The state effectively breaks up foreign-owned plantations into smaller non-union plantations owned by local producers. By 1965, United Fruit no longer directly owns any land in Ecuador and only sporadically purchases fruit to cover shortfalls., media: http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/ecuador.gif, mediacredit: lib.utexas.edu, background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: In the late 1950s in Ecuador, Tenguel, a large United Fruit Company-owned plantation, falls victim to Panama disease and hundreds of workers are dismissed. A growing peasant agrarian reform movement culminates in March of 1962 when workers invade and seize Tenguel. United Fruit is forced to abandon the zone and the government undertakes contentious agrarian reform. The state effectively breaks up foreign-owned plantations into smaller non-union plantations owned by local producers. By 1965, United Fruit no longer directly owns any land in Ecuador and only sporadically purchases fruit to cover shortfalls.

content.$t: endyear: 1960, displaydate: 1950-1960, headline: United Fruit exiles Guatemalan president, text: In 1951, Jacobo Arbenz becomes president of Guatemala, the first democratically elected leader of a Central American country. The following year, Arbenz nationalizes a quarter million acres of unused United Fruit land to redistribute to peasants, and leaves only productive fields under company possession. Enraged, United Fruit, along with the support of the American government, begins an aggressive public relations campaign painting Arbenz as a communist. In 1953 President Truman authorizes CIA action that launches a military coup ousting Arbenz and returning expropriated holdings to United Fruit. This operation begins a series of rightist military dictatorships and a 36-year civil war in Guatemala in which over 200,000 indigenous Maya Guatemalans are massacred in a genocide., media: http://history105.libraries.wsu.edu/fall2014/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2014/08/1085212980_8e78adc357.jpg, mediacredit: history105.libraries.wsu.edu, background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: In 1951, Jacobo Arbenz becomes president of Guatemala, the first democratically elected leader of a Central American country. The following year, Arbenz nationalizes a quarter million acres of unused United Fruit land to redistribute to peasants, and leaves only productive fields under company possession. Enraged, United Fruit, along with the support of the American government, begins an aggressive public relations campaign painting Arbenz as a communist. In 1953 President Truman authorizes CIA action that launches a military coup ousting Arbenz and returning expropriated holdings to United Fruit. This operation begins a series of rightist military dictatorships and a 36-year civil war in Guatemala in which over 200,000 indigenous Maya Guatemalans are massacred in a genocide.

content.$t: endyear: 1970, displaydate: 1950-1970, headline: Introducing the Cavendish, text: Due to the spread of Panama Disease, Gros Michel becomes virtually extinct, and the banana industry is saved by the wide-scale adoption of the disease-resistant Cavendish, developed by Standard Fruit (today known as Dole). Whereas the Gros Michel could simply be cut down by the bunch and tossed into ships’ cargo holds, the Cavendish needs to be handled delicately. The industry develops methods of boxing, bagging and branding bananas via the sticker. The project is so successful that it leads to an oversupply of bananas. Prices drop precipitously., media: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1c/Bananas_white_background.jpg, mediacredit: upload.wikimedia.com, background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: Due to the spread of Panama Disease, Gros Michel becomes virtually extinct, and the banana industry is saved by the wide-scale adoption of the disease-resistant Cavendish, developed by Standard Fruit (today known as Dole). Whereas the Gros Michel could simply be cut down by the bunch and tossed into ships’ cargo holds, the Cavendish needs to be handled delicately. The industry develops methods of boxing, bagging and branding bananas via the sticker. The project is so successful that it leads to an oversupply of bananas. Prices drop precipitously.

content.$t: endyear: 1978, displaydate: 1974-1978, headline: United Fruit investigation, text: The Securities and Exchange Commission launches an investigation against United Fruit after it learns that the company gave a $1.25 million bribe to the president of Honduras. United Fruit pleads guilty to bribery. The scandal is resolved for a fine of $14,000. The Honduran government is overthrown and Costa Rica threatens to evict United Fruit from its territory., media: http://bananarepublicatours.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/chiquita-banana-girl-miranda.jpg, mediacredit: bannaa republicatours.com, background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: The Securities and Exchange Commission launches an investigation against United Fruit after it learns that the company gave a $1.25 million bribe to the president of Honduras. United Fruit pleads guilty to bribery. The scandal is resolved for a fine of $14,000. The Honduran government is overthrown and Costa Rica threatens to evict United Fruit from its territory.

content.$t: endyear: 2015, displaydate: 1990-today, headline: "Panama disease" strikes with a vengeance, text: A new strain of Panama disease appears in Taiwan and begins to spread throughout South East Asia and northern Australia. Thousands of hectares of Cavendish are destroyed, and multinationals like Chiquita begin to invest in research around what is speculated to be a Cavendish replacement for an inevitable future: Panama disease will hit Latin America., media: http://www.freshfruitportal.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/4-01-Moco-Notorio-en-Racimos-y-Frutos-79-_-panorama.jpg, mediacredit: freshfruitportal.com, mediacaption:   , background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: A new strain of Panama disease appears in Taiwan and begins to spread throughout South East Asia and northern Australia. Thousands of hectares of Cavendish are destroyed, and multinationals like Chiquita begin to invest in research around what is speculated to be a Cavendish replacement for an inevitable future: Panama disease will hit Latin America.

content.$t: endyear: 2007, displaydate: 2007, headline: Unpeeling more controversy, text: Chiquita is fined $25 million by the U.S. Department of Justice for payments made to an acknowledged “terrorist organization” in Colombia. Dole is sued in U.S. courts for using the pesticide chemical DBCP that renders workers sterile. The case is the first of five lawsuits regarding Central and South American worker claims of sterilization after exposure to the pesticide. Other growers and manufacturers are named as defendants in these cases., media: http://business-humanrights.org/sites/default/files/images/7186.jpg, mediacredit: business-humanrights.org, background: #333333

gsx$text.$t: Chiquita is fined $25 million by the U.S. Department of Justice for payments made to an acknowledged “terrorist organization” in Colombia. Dole is sued in U.S. courts for using the pesticide chemical DBCP that renders workers sterile. The case is the first of five lawsuits regarding Central and South American worker claims of sterilization after exposure to the pesticide. Other growers and manufacturers are named as defendants in these cases.
